page.title: 17Garvald Housing
page.content: There is reference to Garvald in documents of the 12th Century, but the olderst houses go back to about 1700. In the 18th C. there were 5 Inns, a brewery, weavers, mason's & many stores. In 1775 a flood swept away most of the cottages. Most of the old pantiled sandstone cottages were built between 1780 & 1810, the land being aquired from the Whittingham & Wemyss estates. In the 1930's the old two roomed cottages on the north side of the street were demolished and replaced by the present council houses. Since 1960 the population has steadily increased many of the old cottages being attractively modernised A small development of 6 bungalows was built where there had been a prisoner of war camp. Only about 10 houses in the area are holiday homes, there used to be many more.
